text: In the largest prisoner swap between the East and West since the Cold War, Russia set free wrongly convicted Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich and others in exchange for Russians held in the U.S.

text: and Europe.

text: Looking forward to seeing my family down here and just recuperating from five years, seven months, and five days of just absolute nonsense by the Russian government.

text: On a false allegation of espionage, his trial was conducted in secret.

text: Former President Trump has been workshopping political attacks on his new Democratic opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: And one that he would like to see stick is, quote, radical left lunatic.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: But as other Republicans criticize her as a San Francisco liberal, more traditional political nomenclature, the strategy is clear.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: Caricature Harris for her past policy positions.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: It's a story by Naomi Lim, White House reporter at The Washington Examiner.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: Naomi, what did you look at?
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: So basically, Kamala Harris has this long record as being, quote unquote, a San Francisco liberal.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: She was a line prosecutor out of Oakland County before she moved to district attorney within sort of SF itself.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: And there she sort of really backed things like being a progressive prosecutor, you know, tried to tackle truancy and things like that eventually as she became sort of
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: California Attorney General.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: But what they're really kind of focusing on is the stuff that she sort of brought up in her 2020 Democratic primary campaign, which, you know, wasn't that long ago.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: But the positions that she came out with at the very beginning sort of fell by the wayside the longer the campaign went on.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: As well as I think there was a lot of pressure on all the candidates at that time to sort of take out these really sort of left positions.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: An example, for example, something like Medicare for All.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: She was a co-sponsor of that when she was a California or a senator from California.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: And when she was asked whether she supported private health insurance, she said, no, let's roll it back, which is something that is in that legislation.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: And then other things like the Green New Deal, for example, is another thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: And then obviously, you know, it was a Black Lives Matter at that time.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: And so she was also underscoring things that she did with cash bail and stuff like that when she was in California.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: And it's these things that Republicans want you to focus on because as part of the Biden administration, President Joe Biden's administration, she has become more centrist.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: And that's something that the campaign is really pushing on.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: They want you to know that she has had this long career.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: She's not a DEI hire, as some Republicans like to say.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: But at the same time, she doesn't hold the positions that she had five years ago.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: Okay, so if you're pursuing independent voters, these types of positions won't resignate.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: Well, that's the idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: They want to really use it as a wedge issue, because I think the idea, the reason that Biden won in 2020 was not only because he could bring together the people like Bernie Sanders after the primary, but also that he could reach out to the people that liked sort of Scranton Joe.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: You know, those white working class voters that are in the Rust Belt states, in the blue wall states of Michigan, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, which are must win states again this year.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: And so for Harris, you know, obviously within the week that she's been the nominee, she's really ginned up the base in terms of those young voters, those voters of color.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: But the idea of her sort of reaching out to this other section of the coalition is something that they want to sort of stop.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: I also, what I thought was interesting is, um, sort of to that mind of these white voters, the idea of like disaffected Republicans that didn't particularly like Trump.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: And I was really curious about whether, you know, these attacks would also hurt Harris, um,
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: with that particular voting bloc.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: But the people that I spoke to sort of said, you know, if you were a never-Trumper, it's because of Trump himself.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: And even if, you know, some of those people actually didn't like Biden because of the age and mental acuity thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: So they were thinking about writing someone in.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: But having Harris on the ballot, they say, is sort of giving them a reason to vote for her rather than write in or stay at home.
speaker: SPEAKER_24

text: We're speaking with Naomi Lim, White House reporter at The Washington Examiner.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: If you've been sneaking in some Olympics watching during your workday, join the club.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: But there's a price that companies could be paying for all that lost productivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: MarketWatch says it's a $2.6 billion hit.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: Here's reporter Charles Passy.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: Charles, what's up here?
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: Well, you know, everybody wants to watch Simone Biles while they're in the middle of their workday.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: And let's just say that may not be such great news for the American industry.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: I mean, really what happens here, and this does come up with other events, but people want to watch the games.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: And the games, you know, they're happening when we're working.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: I mean, they're in France or whatever.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: You know what the time difference is.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: So it just is a daily dilemma.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: There was a company, UKG.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: It's a company that sort of looks at the labor market.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: They did a survey via the Harris Poll.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: It's a good survey that said 12.3 million Americans plan to watch the games during work hours.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: And they plan to spend at least six hours playing.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: watching those games.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: So we kind of did the math.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: That equates to about 74 million hours of Olympic viewing.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: And given that the average hourly wage for Americans is $35, do the math, that's $2.6 billion in lost productivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: Wow.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: All right, so I guess an argument could be made.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: Maybe because of the time difference, we're watching the Olympics from France during our lunch break, and maybe that shouldn't count against lost productivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: Well, I mean...
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: Let's just say the survey took into account watching without the boss's permission.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: So I'm going to say that's not lunchtime.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: But Gordon, it does actually get even worse for companies.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: You know, the survey, I mean, we kind of knew that this was a solid block of hours that we could say was kind of, you know, done behind the boss's back.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: The survey looked at some other factors.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: 7.6 million Americans say they plan to call in six days.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: to watch the game.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: Oh, wow.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: And 4.7 million plan to skip work without notice to watch the game.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: That's not factored into the 2.6 billion.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: The problem is that we don't know what the hours are.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: Like, we don't kind of know.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: But let's just say that 2.6 billion is probably a lowball estimate.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: And, you know, given, you know, what we saw, for example, with March Madness,
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: where the figure was estimated to be a $9.6 billion productivity loss, I would guess that the Olympics hit is probably much greater than $2.6 billion.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: But, Gordon, it's very honorable of you to suggest that hardworking Americans are only doing this on their lunch break.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: I appreciate that.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: Something tells me that's not the case.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: And, Gordon, I won't ask you what you're doing on your day, but something tells me these Americans are sneaking in all sorts of Olympics viewing times.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: So how should employers manage this?
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: Well, you know, I talked to HR experts, and they said, let the employees have their day.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: I mean, basically, if you talk to enough HR experts about this, the general sense is ease up a little bit.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: Let people have some fun.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: You don't want to be remembered as the employer, as the boss who went around policing everybody saying, you're watching Simone Biles?
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: I don't like this or whatever.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: You know, you don't you don't want to be too, you know, heavy handed in your approach.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: Thanks, Charles.
